content.question:
Researchers from a national research organization investigated which platform (television, social media, newspaper, Internet, etc.) United States adults prefer to use to obtain their news. In <math alttext="2016" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>2016</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, of the <math alttext="200" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>200</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> randomly selected United States adults that were surveyed, <math alttext="114" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>114</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> selected television as their preferred platform. In <math alttext="2018" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>2018</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, of the <math alttext="200" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>200</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> randomly selected United States adults that were surveyed, <math alttext="98" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>98</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> selected television as their preferred platform. The conditions for inference are met. A <math alttext="95" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>95</mn></math> percent confidence interval for the difference in the population proportions of United States adults that use television as their preferred platform for obtaining news between <math alttext="2016" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>2016</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="2018" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>2018</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="open parenthesis, 2016" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>2016</mn><mo>⁢</mo><mtext> </mtext><mo>⁢</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> minus <math alttext="2018, close parenthesis" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>2018</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> was found to be <math alttext="open parenthesis, negative 0.02 comma 0.18, close parenthesis" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mo>-</mo><mn>0.02</mn></mpadded><mo>,</mo><mpadded><mn>0.18</mn></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded></math>.
Based on the interval, is it reasonable for the researchers to claim that there is convincing statistical evidence that the population proportion of United States adults that use television as their preferred method to obtain news differed between <math alttext="2016" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>2016</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="2018" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>2018</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> ?

choices.label: No, because the researchers should have used a greater confidence level to obtain convincing evidence.

No, because zero is included in the interval there is not convincing statistical evidence that the population proportion differed between <math alttext="2016" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>2016</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="2018" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>2018</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>.

Yes, because zero is included in the interval there is convincing statistical evidence that the population proportion differed between <math alttext="2016" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>2016</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="2018" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>2018</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>.

Yes, because most of the interval is positive there is convincing statistical evidence that the population proportion increased from <math alttext="2016" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>2016</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> to <math alttext="2018" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>2018</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>.

Yes, because <math alttext="0.57" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.57</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> is greater than <math alttext="0.49" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.49</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> there is convincing statistical evidence that the population proportion decreased from <math alttext="2016" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>2016</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> to <math alttext="2018" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>2018</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>.

content.answer: No, because zero is included in the interval there is not convincing statistical evidence that the population proportion differed between <math alttext="2016" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>2016</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="2018" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>2018</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>.
